awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Self-sustainable Water Leak Detection System for Buildings
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project involves developing printable sensors and computational materials to create infrastructure-scale sensing surfaces. It moves sensing and computation from discrete chips and individual devices to large-scale materials that can sense, communicate, and compute with no batteries or external power.  This approach solves a key challenge in modern Internet-of-Things devices, making it easier to monitor the health of physical and energy infrastructure. For example, building wraps that sense problems like leaks or mold can speed and lessen the costs of diagnosing and repairing structural or aesthetic issues. Such materials would sense and report the condition of a physical structure, proactively alert residents if some area requires maintenance, and immediately notify the owners of structural damage. This improved feedback loop would reduce the burden of maintaining $4.5 trillion worth of physical infrastructure in the United States alone by proactively directing engineers and technicians to the most vulnerable parts of a structure. Similarly, being able to ambiently sense the presence of various substances like water, oil, or carbon monoxide can have significant safety, economic, health, and environmental benefits.

This I-Corps project proposes sensors that are printable, inexpensive to manufacture and purchase, and self-sustainable in terms of energy and durability. Two of our technical approaches are active, producing enough energy in the presence of various substances like water to be able to communicate the event of a leak wirelessly to a remote receiver. Another approach is passive, requiring a scan to determine a change in antenna properties to determine the presence of water. All three techniques use non-toxic materials and are inexpensive: $1.50/sq foot and lower for the sensing and power generation material, and $0.01/transmitter (passive) to $5/transmitter (active, which can be connected to multiple sensors). The goal is to design a process that can be used with standard commercial printing techniques to produce large sheets of plastic or paper (such as with building wrap) at meters per second.  The resulting material is thin and flexible and easily deployed.  The sensing material should last for decades allowing it to be deployed in hard-to-access locations. Prototypes and proof-of-concept devices have been shown in the lab for each approach.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The team conducted 120 interviews of potential customers for water leak detection materials. After investigating the risk tolerance to water leaks of hotels, rental properties, high value retail properties, hospitals, properties with outdoor flyways, oil pipelines and processing facilities, steam pipe physical plants, and properties with roof-top gardens, the team discovered data center managers seem to be the most worried about water leaks, have some of the costiest property at risk, and are already deploying technology to mitigate such leaks.  

These customers require a "heartbeat" signal that provides them assurance that the system is working, even when no water events are triggering an alarm.

The team determined several ways a minimal viable product could be made that fit the needs of data center managers. First, the team investigated small thin batteries that could be manufactured as part a carpet underlayment and distributed in regular patterns throughout the carpet. When the carpet becomes wet in a given area, the water activates the batteries in that area which in turn power radios that broadcase a unique ID that identifies where in the data center the leak is occuring. Several batteries were successfully created that generate power with a a few millileters of water. This direction seems the most immediately manufacturable.

However, some method of creating a "heartbeat" is needed to reassure managers that the system continues to operate even if no water event is occurring.  One method for such a heartbeat is to use ambient backscatter technologies where remote radio transmissions power resonators in the carpet whose oscillations can be detected remotely. These resonators would be the same as the resonators used in the water-activated battery radios. Thus, as long as the resonators respond to excitation by a remote radio, the data center manager has some assurance that the system is working.

A simpler method, however, is to create a carpet underlayment that consists of printed, braided electrodes whose mutual capacitance changes whenever water seeps between the electrodes.   Since power is run to each server rack in a data center already, the system could be powered by simple electrical leads penetrating the carpet. As the system is tied to the power mains, it could actively sample every second, providing the "heartbeat" required by the target customers. This system is the simplest and most cost-effective discovered to date for the data center application. Prototypes showed the system's ability to detect water without being confused by other sources of capacitance change, such as a worker walking on the data center carpet.


Last Modified: 11/18/2022
Modified by: Thad Starner
